Refiloe and the 
 washed chickens 
 
 Marion Drew 
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 It was the first weding in the Tenane
 
 family, and Refiloe had never ben so
 excited in her life. 
 
 "I’m going to be Palesa’s bridesmaid, with
 a new dres and shoes!" she said to her
 chickens. 
 
 
 Refiloe told her chickens everything.
 
 Her father had given the chickens to her
 as a birthday present, and she loved
 them very much. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 "Take those dirty scrufy chickens out of 
 
 here Refiloe!" shouted her mother, "I don’t 
 want them anywhere near this weding 
 tent." 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Refiloe shoed her chickens out of the
 tent. 
 
 
 "Run away you sily things." she said, "I
 don’t want you to be eaten at Palesa’s
 
 weding!" 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 "Mme says that this is going to be the best weding ever 
 sen in Malealea," Refiloe told her chickens, "and she says 
 that I can help al the older girls with the coking." 
 
 The chickens paid no atention to her. 
 
 
 "Refiloe!" caled her mother from inside, "leave those 
 chickens of yours and come and help me with these pots 
 please!" 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Refiloe’s mother was very proud of her house, and wanted it to be perfect for
 the weding. She cleaned and washed and scrubed and scoured and 
 
 polished everything in sight. When she had finished, there was not a single
 speck of dust anywhere. 
 The chickens poked their heads inside the front dor. "Out!" shouted
 
 Refiloe’s mother, "out you scrufy things with your dirty fet and beaks!"
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Refiloe folowed her chickens out into the yard. 
 "Mme is right, you are a disgrace," she scolded them 
 So Refiloe thought for a while. Sudenly she smiled and said 
 
 to herself, "I have an excelent idea." 
 She went and filed a bucket with water from the spring. 
 
 Refiloe had a lot of trouble catching her chickens. They did 
 not think that a bath was such a god idea. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Refiloe put the first chicken into the
 bucket of water. 
 
 It clucked at the top of its voice and
 flaped its wings like crazy. 
 "Hold stil you sily thing," Refiloe shouted,
 
 "this won’t take long!" 
 When Refiloe wiped the chicken’s nose
 
 and eyes it sudenly went limp and
 floped over the side of the bucket.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 "This is no time to slep," said Refiloe. 
 
 She gave it a god shake to get al the 
 water out. 
 
 
 "If you are not going to wake up now, I’l 
 have to put you somewhere to dry nicely," 
 she said. She laid the chicken out on the 
 
 gras to dry. 
 
 
 The chicken lay completely stil. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Refiloe washed each and every one of her chickens.
 
 Each and every one of them went limp and flopy before she
 was finished with it. 
 She put al those eight chickens in a row on the gras to dry.
 
 Not one of them moved a single feather. 
 "I’l leave them to slep a litle," Refiloe thought to herself,
 
 and of she went to check on the moroho. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Mme Ngwe and Mme Pedi were Refiloe’s 
 aunts. They did not like each other at al. 
 
 The aunts had ben preparing for 
 months for Palesa’s weding, but they 
 would not even think about riding 
 
 together in the same taxi. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Mme Ngwe spoted Refiloe’s chickens laid out to dry.
 "What a nice litle snack for me to take home!" she said to
 
 herself. 
 She tok of her chale and carefuly wraped al those
 chickens up in it. 
 
 Not a single chicken moved. 
 "Perfect!" she smiled, "now I shal put them somewhere
 
 where Mme Pedi wil not ever find them," and she put the
 bundle around the corner among the pumpkin vines.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 12  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Mme Pedi decided to make her famous pumpkin dish. She tok her big bowl
 and went of to the vegetable garden. 
 
 In the vegetable garden she saw Mme Ngwe’s bundle under the pumpkin 
 vine. She undid the bundle. 
 Out fel al eight chickens. "Eish!" she cried jumping back in surprise.
 
 "Oh, you are the cleanest, pretiest chickens! Just ready for my pot," she
 croned. 
 "Now, where shal I hide you my darlings?" Mme Pedi chuckled, "I’l have to
 
 find a very god place," she said walking round the house. 
 "I know," she said at last, "I’l put you on the rof!" 
 
 Mme Pedi climbed up onto the garden wal and put the chickens in a row on
 the thatched rof. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 13  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 14  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The next day the sun rose in god time for the weding. Refiloe was up first
 and went to se her chickens. 
 She saw that they were no longer lying on the gras. 
 
 "They must be nicely dry by now. I’m sure they have gone to lok for their
 breakfast," she said. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 15  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Palesa’s weding was wonderful. 
 Those chickens did not get up of the rof to join in when al 
 
 the bridesmaid ladies danced into the yard. 
 Not one of the chickens stired when the church choir sang 
 
 in their loudest, swetest voices. 
 The chickens were stil lying on the rof when the priest gave 
 his sermon. 
 
 They did not even twitch a feather when the pigs and 
 Refiloe’s grandfather al snored loudly in the midle of the 
 
 sermon. 
 Not one fot of those chickens trembled when shep 
 wandered into the tent, nearly knocking over the weding 
 
 cake. 
 
 
 
 
 
 16  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 It was only when the grom’s father was
 halfway through his spech that things
 
 started to change on that rof. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 17  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The first chicken spread its wings and flew onto Mme Ngwe’s bosom. Mme
 Pedi next to her started gigling. 
 Another chicken flew up onto Mme Ngwe’s new duku. The people at the next
 
 table tried not to laugh. 
 The lady next to Mme Ngwe put her head down onto the table, "Ai, ai,
 ai, he, he, he!" she cackled. 
 
 Al the other chickens decided to join the first two. You couldn’t se Mme
 Ngwe for al those chickens! 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 18  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 19  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The guests screamed with laughter. 
 
 The men had to hold onto their belies. 
 The women roled around in their chairs. 
 The boys and girls were hanging onto each other. 
 
 The grandmothers could hardly breathe for laughing. 
 The grandfathers stamped their walking sticks. 
 Then the two aunts loked at each other and started gigling. Mme Pedi
 
 opened her mouth wide with laughter. Mme Ngwe threw back her head and
 laughed until al her chins shok. 
 
 Refiloe couldn’t believe it! 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 20  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 21  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Al the guests agred that it was the best weding entertainment ever
 known in Malealea. 
 
 "Oh you are so lucky!" Refiloe said to her chickens as she put them into their
 cop for the night, "Mme says that she wil never put you in the super pot."
 "But lok how dirty you are again," she told them, "I think I’l have to give you
 
 another wash tomorow!"
